titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Weather still cold and unpleasant. Sale in the morning, for a few minutes. Long walk which I found beneficial.— Something of a Rheumatic complaint. A few tours towards Evening in the Voorhout. Remainder in the usual speculations.

2. Letter to Pitcairn. Lesson of Italian at Bielfeld’s. Walk afterwards with him.— Mr: Macqueen. Tour in the Voorhout in the afternoon. 28th: Book of the Orlando Furioso. Tale of Jocundo. compared it with the Joconde of La Fontaine. A pleasant, but very licentious tale.

3. Wrote a little in the forenoon. Walk in the wood. Sale in the afternoon. Closed for the books. Walk to Scheveling. Read the 29th. book of Hoole’s Ariosto, which ends with the third volume. The tale of Isabella’s Death is interesting, though Extravagant. The translation still heavy and dull.

4. Sale finished this morning. Lesson of Italian. Walk with Bielfeld. Began upon the fourth volume of Hoole’s Ariosto with the 30th: book. Evening at the play. Alexis at Justine. I remember to have seen it before: Le Claveçin. Italian extravagance and Italian music. Reading Cicero’s Offices. But have neither translation nor notes. Find the latin not sufficiently familiar. If I pass the winter here must endeavour to make it so.
5. Wrote to Mr: King. Walk in the wood; overtook Mr: Levsen. Stroll’d with him till after four o’clock. Autumn growing cool. Afternoon and evening employed in pleasing studies.

6. Morning Walk. Dr: Macqueen dined with. us. Visit to Madam Veerman, who return’d on Monday from the Country. Evening at the french Minister’s tea and card party. He was very civil. Quadrille with Mlle: Kempenaar & Mlle: Bicker, and Mr: Bosset. My usual afternoon employment altogether omitted.

7. Books from the last sale. Hope to have now for some time a respite. My library accumulated somewhat largely.— Lesson of Italian. Walk with Bielfeld. Afternoon and Evening busy having partly to repair the omissions of yesterday.

8. Weather much like that I experienced at the same Season last year at Helvoetsluys.— Miscellaneous morning reading. Letter from Mr: Pinckney. He was about to embark for America. From Mr: Bourne. Must endeavour to write a little in the forenoon.— Walk alone in the wood.— Afternoon and Evening employed as usual. Much embarassed with my books.

9. Rainy day.— Lesson of Italian.— Wrote a little in the forenoon. Walk alone in the Wood.— Symptoms of approaching Winter— After dinner Mr: Macqueen and the Doctor. Evening in the pleasures of study. Must remember the precept I have lately read in Cicero’s Offices. That all virtue consists in Action, and that too much time should not be devoted to contemplation and the pursuit of knowledge.

10. Weather growing quite cold. Wrote a little in the forenoon. A habit which I have too much omitted of late, and must endeavour to resume. Long walk in the wood and round the town.— Called in the beginning of the Evening at Mr: Scholten’s. No body at home.— Remainder at Mlle. Laurenzi’s. Company principally unknown. Cards. Whist with Madam Cneiff, Reuterswerd and another Gentleman whom I knew not. Finished however quite early. Home before ten.

11. Forenoon in the library. Too much time spent in this manner. Lesson of Italian omitted. Long walk before dinner.— Evening at the play. Les deux billets. A Harlequinade of Florian. I have seen it many years ago at Paris. La Villageoise enlevée, translation from the Italian, La Villanella rapita. The music excellent; the play extravagant as usual.— Tacitus’s treatise upon the Germans.

12. Letters from England. Dined at M. de Schubart’s. Company not very large. Mr: & Mrs: Schimmelpennick. Mr: Van der Goes. Sir Robert Barclay. Mm: Scholten. knew most of the others. M. Julien gave me a seat to return home. Evening in reading.

13. Endeavouring to write in the forenoon. Hitherto much in vain. Lesson of Italian omitted on Tuesday. Rainy day. Walk however before dinner. M. Noël’s party in the Evening, which I did not attend.— Not very well.

14. Wrote a couple of letters in the forenoon. Called on Mr: Van Leyden. He is not in town. At Bielfeld’s for a lesson of Italian, but our instructor failed us. Walk with him in the wood. The two Macqueen’s after dinner. finished the 4th: volume & 40th: book of the Orlando.

15. Weather dull. Wrote a little in the forenoon, but not enough. Long walk towards Loosduynen. Bielfeld called with Mr Buckner while I was out.— Caught in the rain.— Began the 5th: vol: of my Ariosto. read the 41st: book.

16. Letters this morning from the Secretary of State. July 23d: in answer to my last Letter to him from London. April 29th:— Wrote him in reply. Lesson of Italian at Bielfeld’s. Walk with him afterwards in the wood.— Have been reading Cicero’s Offices and his treatise upon friendship. They are full of instruction, and of the best philosophy, excepting that of Christianity.

17. Writing again in the forenoon. Lesson of Italian, for that we lost last week. Short walk before dinner.— Mr: Allen. 43d: book of the Orlando. A very long one, and among the best. Walk towards Delft.— Weather fine, but cool. Evening spent according to my present custom. List of Gibbon’s books cited in his History. Cicero de Senectute.

18. Writing in the forenoon. Lesson of Italian. Short rainy walk in the wood. Met Reuterswerd.— Doctor M’Queen. He is on his return to England. my brother went with him to Rotterdam.— Mr: Marshall. Evening, comme de coutume.

19. Rain all the forenoon. Long walk, weather clearing up.— Mr: Marshall dined with me.— Caesar’s Commentaries.— The treatise upon Rhetoric in the collection of Cicero’s works.— “For all a Rhetorician’s rules” &c.

20. Mr: Marshall here in the morning, and proceeded to Rotterdam. On my return from my walk before dinner, found my brother come back. Finished at length the 46th: and last book of Hoole’s Ariosto. Of the whole work my opinion varies little from that I had form’d of the first books. The versification in general is smooth and easy: but the charm of interest which the Italian readers find so powerful in the original, is not transfused into the translation. The madness of Orlando forms but a very small part of the Poem, and I cannot find any centre of combination to the multifarious characters and adventures which are spread through a Poem longer than the Iliad and Odyssey both.— Evening at Mr: Noël’s. Company large. Home early.

21. Lesson of Italian. Walk with Bielfeld. Overtook Madam Veerman in the wood. Attended her.— Read the first book of Dwight’s Conquest of Canäan. The verse is as good as that of Hoole. But there is little invention, and nothing of the delight or surprize which constitutes the great excellence of epic verse.— Caesar’s Commentaries and the Rhetorics addressed to Herennius.

22. Writing in the forenoon. My brother received from Mr: Walker at Rotterdam, a Boston Centinel of September 24. containing the President’s address to the People of the United States, dated the 17th:— Evening at the play. Le Conteur ou les deux Postes, a very indifferent Comedy. Lucette et Lucas ou le Moulin an Opera. Music very good; singing better than usual.— Cicero de inventione Rhetorica. The work addressed to Herennius is not Cicero’s, though always added to the collection of his works.
23. Rainy day. Walk however in the wood. My brother dined with some Americans at the Marechal de Turenne. Morning writing. No Italian Lesson. Evening amusement and studies.
24. Letter this morning from my brother Charles. Septr: 7. with the Papers. Writing. Walk to the barrier in the wood. Remainder of the day as usual.
25. Weather variable.— Letter to Mr: Bourne. To my brother Charles. Lesson of Italian, at Bielfeld’s. Walk in the Wood.— Caesar’s Commentaries on the Gallic Wars.

26. Writing. Lesson of Italian. Walk with Bielfeld. He says Frederic William the 1st: king of Prussia had one general form of answer to all petitions—memorials—reports—&c which did not please him. It was to write with his own hand in the margin kiss my—! Thousands of these answers are extant to this day.— Evening at Madam Cneiff’s. Quadrill with Mm: Bosset. Madam Scholten and Baron Schubart.

27. Fair cold weather— Walk in the wood. met Bielfeld.— No party at M. Noël’s. Finished reading Caesar Commentaries upon his wars in Gaul. the 8th: book by Hirtius. Looked into Crevier’s Roman History for an account of that period, and into Plutarch’s Life of Caesar. Much pleased with the last.

28. Fair weather, but very cold. Visit to Mr: Westrik, member of the East-India Committee. He was not at home. Long walk across the downs towards Scheveling. Lesson of Italian at Bielfeld’s. Finished reading the sixth book of Tasso’s Jerusalem, and the interesting story of Erminia.— In the Evening, the first book of Caesar’s Commentaries on the Civil War.

29. Called on Mr Westrik again this morning and found him at home. But he is not a member of the East-India Committee as I was informed, but of the West-India Committee. Went to the East India house. The members went this morning to Amsterdam where I must send the papers.— Long walk again, across the Downs to the Sea beyond Scheveling.— Afternoon and Evening as usual.

30. Writing in the forenoon. No lesson of Italian. Suspend this study for the present. Walk with Bielfeld to Scheveling. Conversation with him on the question upon the morality of Brutus’s killing Caesar.— Montesquieu has solved it properly. Caesar had left the Romans no other remedy against his usurpation, but assassination.— 10th: book of the Conquest of Canaan The vision of futurity has merit, but is too long. The last 200 lines might have been better omitted. The astronomical revelations are unnecessary and improper. They weaken the effect of the whole. A descent from the millenium, the general judgment and the consummation of all things to a disquisition upon the Copernican system may be ranked among the examples of Bathos.— Caesar’s Commentaries on the Civil Wars.

31. Writing in the forenoon.— Long walk beyond Loosduynen.— Finished reading the Conquest of Canäan. Here I shall suspend for the present my reading of Epic Poetry which I have continued from the 29th: of April.— Evening at Mr: Veerman’s.— Music.

Day. Rise between 7. and 8. Translate a page from Tacitus, and read to understand him thoroughly, for an antient author may be read translated without being understood. At 1/2 past nine breakfast.— Dress. write an hour or. two.— Walk for exercise till dinner time, between three and four. After dinner have hitherto pass’d about an hour in reading poetry, which ceases with this month.— Evening reading Caesar’s Commentaries. Bed at 11.
